comments.text:
I'm From Brazil, got a ride from here in 10 minutes with a trucker to cuzco.
The only thing that i think is good to point is that, while i was there, an old man was by my side. He was desperated because i was hitchhiking, saying that it wasn't safe.
On the other hand, trucker said that that it was common for him to take hitchhickers there.
Take your on conclusions.
Mine is, i would do that again

To get in this place i asked a man on the street where was the road to cuzco and he indicated me a m

Nice spot, no shade
We get a ride straight to Chiclayo but I think it's easy to go to Sullana o Piura

Took the bus to Cono Norte from the centre of town and then walked a few minutes. Barely had time to drop our bags and lift our thumbs that an Italian tourist with a rented car stopped to give us a lift. The road between Arequipa and Puno is absolutely gorgeous!
Many trucks passing by. Rather go early
On the panamerican highway its super easy to find a hitch. Loads of trucks. (3 people)
Don't wait at the bottom where the shops end. Stand as close as possible to the toll gate and use a sign with destination. We got a lot more reactions that way.

Two guys, obvious foreigners, with our backpacks:
This is basically the place which is in the description of Arequipa. Once you found the right bus to go to Uchumayo you have to hop off at the final stop. From the main square just go straight down to where the highway is, maybe not quite obvious from the first sight but you won't miss it. We put ourselves about a 100 metres after the toll collect, at the very end of all the little shops. It took as more than one hour until a veeeeery slow truck
We waited here to get to Suillana

This was a good spot for getting north: Behind the 'grifo - nor oriente' - it's in the direction of Lambayeque, you can easily take a bus. There are some 'peatonales' here, so the trucks have to go slowly and you can just take them ;-)
It's nice waiting here, because you can enjoy a cold coconut and drink it :p

A nice spot to wait for getting north here. You can from Piura get a ride here (or to Suillana) and then continue from here - for instance to Mancora. The Panamericana does not have a lot of traffic from here to the north at the coast, because there's another Panamericana more in the east - which is shorter if you directly want to get to ecuador.

Good to get north here - you'll find some shadow under the tree!
Though - all in all - it's difficult taking this road, because there are two Panamericanas parallel here - and this one is the one with less traffic ;-)
Here is a Peaje. All the cars have to drive very slowly, so it´s a very good spot to stop trucks for going north. We waited for 40 Min and got a direct ride to Chimbote.

If you want to hitchhike to Cuzco, first you need to go to Juliaca. It's unlikely that you'll get a ride direct to Cusco in Puno. Good news is, is not dificult to get to Juliaca. I got in this place by foot, it was a long way, if you can catch a mini van, i recommend, they only cost about 60 centimos (cents in peruvian money).
I got a ride to Juliaca in about 30 minutes in this place.

Heading to south.
Right after the exit from the gas station. The traffic flow is high here.

It's not really comfortable for trucks to stop in this place. But we had a good luck to stop one at night in less than 10 minutes.

Heading to south.
There is a lot of space to stop. Cars a passing by relatively slowly after the turn and can see you from the big distance. Traffic is good, both trucks and private cars.

The sun is really intensive here, be careful.

Good spot to start a way to Ecuador in the morning. There is a shadow from the road sign that helps to hide from the intensive sun. I walked there from the center of Mancora, but you can also take a taxi for few soles. The spot is in about 50 meters before the gas station and bridge.
There is a sleeping policeman before, so cars and trucks are passing by slowly. I get a ride to Tumbes after one hour (not bad as for the low morning traffic).
Out of Cuzco, low speed and many trucks goes direction to Lima.

Salida al norte.
Toma un micro "Nueva California "A" hasta la ultima parada. Alli esta "Sunat", donde revisan los camiones. Cuando los camioneros salen es un momento bueno para preguntar a ellos directamente.

Direction at Huancayo.
It is a parking area at the end of town.

Direccion a Huancayo.
Es un lugar para estacionar en el fin de pueblo.

Direction at Cusco.
Take a bus "Huayucachi" (1 sol). You have to get out at the last stop. And next go up a little by the road (100m).

Direccion a Cusco.
Toma un micro "Huayucachi" (1 sol) hasta la ultima parada y tienes que caminar un poco arriba por la carretera (100m). Alla hay un letrero grande "Claro".

Direction at Cusco.
Take a bus #4 up to last stop.

Direccion a Cusco.
Toma un micro #4 hasta la ultima parada.

Direction at Cusco.
Take a colectivo up to "San Jeronimo". You have to get out at "Bulevar". And next go a little up to the hill by the road.

Direccion a Cusco.
Toma un colectivo a "Sn Jeronimo". Salgas en "Bulevar" y tienes que caminar un poco arriba por la carretera.

Direction at Cusco.
Take a microbus #4 up to "Mirador". Just go up to the last stop. At the entrance to "Mirador" it is the place for HH.

Dirección a Cusco.
Toma un micro #4 hasta "Mirador". Salga en la ultima parada. Es un lugar bueno para hacer dedo.

Direction at Cusco.
It is good place close to a bridge in the end of village.

Direccion a Cusco.
Un buen lugar al final de pueblo cerca de un puente.
December 2024, 9:30 a.m., Some people are nice but Peru is no good country for hitchhiking and many people want to have money
December 2024, 7:30 a.m., Some people are nice but Peru is no good country for hitchhiking and many people want to have money
November 2024, 21:00, nice helpful people, but Peru is not really good for hitchhiking and many people want to have money :(

Peaje. I tried for 2 hours closer to the city, with no luck. (close to petrol station)
No shade, but got picked up quite quickly. There is a space before and after peaje. 
A bit of Venezuelanos are trying to hitchhike, which can make drivers a bit more scared.

Went with @crazyrik. (4 people)
I'd say we were really lucky to get a truck here, but pretty sure if you wait long enough a big truck is gonna take you pretty far.
ok place, most people drive to Arequipa but if zpu get a truck it will quite possibly go to the Bolivian border

Heading to Lima.
Under the pedestrian bridge, where old Panamericana connects with new one. 

There is a turn of the main road before, but traffic goes pretty fast. There is still enough place for even for trucks to stop.

After my conversation with policeman, he left me on the same spot without problems. It seems that he took care just about my security. There is a strange district of the town  In front of the place.

Heading to Chiclayo.
Trucks are going from East to the coast direction. During the afternoon there were not a lot of them. I suppose more trucks are passing during the evening and night time, because of the hot weather.

The road side is good enough for cars to stop. There is a shadow from the hill. Be ready that a ride to Chiclayo will be long. Despite less than 300km of distance, trucks need up to 10 hours to make it by the mountain road. (+time for stops).

Take a "colectivo" at km 11.
There is a police station.

Toma un colectivo hasta km 11. Es un estacion de policia.

Looked like a good stop but we had such a hard time hitchhiking to the border with Bolivia (there were two of us, a guy and a girl). A beautiful green Volvo truck ended up stopping and taking us to the next town where we were stranded for three hours.

Peaje. Sunny, there is a place to stop. It costed me 10 soles to get here.
I gave up after 2 hours, but I heard that trucks are going in afternoon.
We (3 People) waited for ages and went down the road. At that spot was a police controlpoint - they helped us by convincing a truck driver.

Heading to south.
Traffic consists of mototaxis and local cars, just few trucks. You can ask the driver to lift you to the road 3N where more trucks pass. 
BE CAREFUL. The sun is pretty intensive here and there are almost no shadow next to the road. Make sure to have a hat, sunscreen and fresh water.

Heading to Jaen.
There is a 24-hours gas station at the exit of town that can be reached walking from the town.

Except taxis there is low local traffic. No trucks. Locals wants money (transportation is a popular business here), but it's possible to negotiate and even ask for a free ride.
My best was to get a ride for 3 soles (less than $1) to Jaen at 9pm. On the way driver took a lot of usual passengers, so part of a ride I spent in a trunk among huge luggage.
Waited a long time. A few trucks passing by. (3 people)
So get off the bus/car earlier, so that you don't end in Aguas Verdes

AS FOREIGNERS: DON'T GO TO AGUAS VERDES! You have to cross the border more in the south, the street is caled 'frontera', I think. We had to take some motos to get there and they were dropping us in the wrong place - so if you take motos: make sure that they drop you at the entrance to Ecuador/exit of Peru and not at the entrance to Peru!!
Im not sure why this spot was so bad but I couldnt get a ride here despite there being a load of trucks and other very hitchable vehicles
